JUDGES: András Sajó;Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Kristina Pardalos;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .

On DATE the applicant ’s husband P.R. fell ill . On DATE a doctor , ORG , who worked at ORG , visited him at his home and prescribed him certain medication . DATE P.R. ’s medical condition had not improved and he had a fever of QUANTITY . The applicant succeeded in contacting PERSON only on DATE . In TIME of the same day P.R. ’s condition substantially worsened and the medical emergency service took him to the PERSON hospital . On DATE , at the applicant ’s request , blood samples were taken from her husband . On CARDINAL DATE P.R. was found to have septicaemia and was transferred to the intensive care unit .

On DATE the applicant ’s husband died in the PERSON hospital . The clinical diagnosis of his death , recorded in the hospital ’s documents , was sepsis . That diagnosis was not confirmed by an autopsy , since the applicant refused CARDINAL .

The applicant requested ORG to appraise the quality of the medical services which ORG and ORG had provided to her husband . On DATE ORG produced an expert report ( no . CARDINALA-CARDINAL - CARDINAL K ) which stipulated that , while treating the applicant ’s husband , ORG had made certain mistakes . In particular , given that P.R. ’s condition was not improving , the doctor had not used all available means to establish factors which would have been important for determining the proper treatment . “ That is to say , having suspected pneumonia [ the doctor ] did not immediately send the patient for an X - ray examination , did not assess the effectiveness of the prescribed medication , and did not send the patient to hospital , as [ the applicable medical instructions ] required ” . Lastly , the experts noted that the head of ORG had not been carrying out the ORG Minister ’s instructions on medical care effectively .

ORG ordered the head of ORG to assure adherence to the ministerial requirements and to evaluate the doctor ’s actions . On DATE ORG was informed that ORG had received a disciplinary sanction by way of a warning .

On DATE the applicant initiated civil proceedings against ORG , the PERSON hospital and GPE , alleging that the medical personnel had failed to carry out their duties properly and that this had caused her husband ’s death .
On DATE ORG ordered the ORG ( the “ FMI ” ) to conduct a deontological examination as regards the circumstances and cause of P.R. ’s death . CARDINAL experts took part in the examination .

On DATE the ORG presented its results in report no . ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) . The report stipulated that P.R. had died from sepsis , noting however that the cause of death had only been established on the basis of a clinical diagnosis . Given that there was no autopsy report , the actual cause of death remained uncertain .

The report also stated that , when treating the applicant ’s husband , ORG had acted properly and without undue delay . The experts concluded that ORG ’s actions had no direct causal link with the death , since the treatment she prescribed was in accordance with the patient ’s condition . They also stated that applicable legislation did not empower a family doctor to compel her patient to go to hospital [ against his will ] . Lastly , the experts found the treatment at ORG to have been appropriate to the patient ’s medical condition .

As regards the treatment which P.R. received at the PERSON hospital , the experts again found it to have been adequate , with the exception of the treatment which P.R. had received in the hospital ’s intensive care unit . Yet the experts noted that it was not possible to ascertain what influence the latter had had on GPE ’s death , since no autopsy had ever been performed .
In sum , there was no direct causal link between either the actions of ORG or the PERSON hospital ’s personnel and the death of the applicant ’s husband .

On DATE the applicant requested ORG to order a supplementary expert report . She noted that the CARDINAL expert reports , no . CARDINALA-CARDINAL - CARDINAL K and no . ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL ( DATE ) , had been contradictory . In the applicant ’s view , the ORG ’s experts were partial and it was necessary to create a new expert commission which would evaluate the quality , objectivity and plausibility of the CARDINAL previous reports , as well as establish the actual cause of her husband ’s death and whether the treatment he had received had been appropriate and effective . That commission was also to establish whether the medical personnel who had treated her late husband had breached any applicable medical instructions .

By a decision of CARDINAL DATE , ORG dismissed the applicant ’s lawsuit as unfounded . The court ’s arguments and reasoning were set out in CARDINAL pages . The applicant ’s lawyer took part in that hearing .

Whilst noting ORG report about certain defects in ORG ’s and PERSON actions , the court nevertheless emphasised that those flaws were of an organisational character ( organizacinio pobudžio ) and had no causal link to the quality of medical services which were provided to P.R. The court furthermore noted that there were no grave ORG mistakes , which ORG would have established .

Referring to ORG guidelines in medical negligence cases and having examined the ORG ’s deontological report no . ORG CARDINAL/CARDINAL in the light of other evidence , ORG found that report credible . It stressed that the cause of death of the applicant ’s husband had only been established from clinical characteristics ( pagal klinikinius požymius ) . Yet , as both experts had noted in their written reports and in person at the hearing , in the absence of an autopsy it had not been possible to ascertain the exact cause of death .

From all the above , the court concluded that the applicant had failed to prove that the doctors had acted in breach of applicable medical norms . Neither had the applicant proved a causal link between the ORG actions and her husband ’s death . ORG also observed that the evidence in the case ruled out the ORG negligence . The court did not address the applicant ’s request for a supplementary expert examination . Lastly , ORG ordered the applicant to cover the other parties’ litigation costs in the sum of CARDINAL NORP litai ( MONEY ) .

The applicant appealed , arguing that the CARDINAL expert reports were contradictory , and requested ORG to order a new expert examination into the circumstances of her husband ’s death . She also claimed that the first - instance court had ordered her to cover the other parties’ litigation costs for too high a sum .

On DATE , at the hearing of ORG , the applicant ’s lawyer requested that the experts of ORG and the ORG be summoned for questioning in open court . ORG granted that request . The lawyer further requested that a new expert examination be carried out , arguing that the CARDINAL reports were contradictory . The court decided to resolve that question after the lawyer submitted the request in writing and formulated his questions to the experts .

It transpires from the record of the hearing of ORG that on DATE the applicant ’s lawyer again requested the court to order a new expert examination . Given that other parties to the proceedings objected to that request , ORG decided to adjourn the hearing until DATE .

On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer reiterated his request for a supplementary expert report . Having considered the lawyer ’s request on the spot , the chamber decided to adjourn the determination of this issue until the parties had made their final submissions . Having heard the parties’ summings - up , ORG adjourned its decision until DATE .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . The court acknowledged that ORG had made certain errors of judgment by not exhausting all means available to diagnose P.R. ’s illness , and by not consulting other doctors when his condition did not improve . Yet the appellate court found no proof that those errors had been the direct cause of P.R. ’s death . The court also had regard to the ORG ’s deontological report to the effect that the measures which ORG and ORG had undertaken were adequate for the physical condition of P.R. The court noted that the ORG ’s conclusions were confirmed and elaborated by CARDINAL experts , who testified before both the first - instance and the appellate courts . For the latter , the applicant ’s allegation that the ORG ’s experts had been partial and not objective was unfounded , even though their conclusion contradicted that of ORG . On the contrary , the court noted that those experts were well qualified , with scientific and pedagogical degrees in their respective fields of medicine .

As to the treatment which P.R. had received in ORG intensive care unit , ORG acknowledged that it had been inadequate . However , given that the applicant herself refused to allow an autopsy , it was not possible to establish what influence that inadequate treatment could have had on ORG death . Consequently , the first - instance court was correct in not finding a causal link between the actions of ORG doctors and the death of the applicant ’s husband .
Lastly , ORG found that the award of litigation costs which the applicant was ordered to pay was in accordance with the recommendations prescribed by ORG .

The applicant lodged a cassation appeal , complaining that the lower courts had not allowed her claim for pecuniary and non - pecuniary damages . She further alleged that the first - instance and appellate courts had evaluated the evidence wrongly , that the expert examination had not been thorough and that important factual circumstances had not been established .

By a ruling of DATE , ORG refused to examine the cassation appeal , noting that the applicant ’s claim in respect of pecuniary and non - pecuniary damages was intrinsically related to her allegation of an erroneous examination of the factual circumstances , but the latter did not fall within ORG jurisdiction . The applicant submitted new cassation appeals . However , on CARDINAL and DATE and CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed them as lodged out of time .

The PERSON on the Medical Practice of Physicians ( PERSON praktikos įstatymas ) stipulates that a doctor who has made a grave error when practising the profession can be deprived of his or her licence . ORG is CARDINAL of the bodies which can propose that a licence be withdrawn ( LAW CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL ) . Moreover , the doctor who has breached the requirements of this law is answerable under the domestic law and regulations ( LAW ) . Furthermore , a special body – the Commission for the Assessment of Doctors’ Professional Competence – exists to assess the professional qualifications of doctors ( LAW ) .

LAW on LAW to their Health ( NORP teisių ir žalos sveikatai atlyginimo įstatymas ) stipulates that patients must be accorded qualified health care . Pursuant to LAW , the damage suffered by patients as a result of the culpable actions of a physician is to be compensated in accordance with the procedure established by LAW .

Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Civil Code provides that any pecuniary damage caused to another person must be fully compensated by the responsible person . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL allows compensation for non - pecuniary damage incurred due to health impairment or a deprivation of life . As regards medical negligence specifically , in the ruling of CARDINAL DATE no . ORG confirmed this right , specifying that , in case of a person ’s death , the spouse , parents and children have the right to request compensation for non - pecuniary damage for their loss . Lastly , LAW provides that an employer is liable to compensation for damage caused by the fault of employees in the performance of their service ( official ) duties .

Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure stipulates that the parties must prove their claims . Pursuant to Article CARDINAL , the court evaluates the probative value of evidence according its own inner belief , basing its conclusions on a comprehensive and objective examination of the facts of the case . Unless the PERSON provides otherwise , no evidence has predetermined value .
In its ruling No . CARDINAL of DATE , ORG noted
